APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [3rd Allotted Day]:

    Resumption of debate on Question (16th December, 1958) proposed to Head 30 in the First Schedule of the Bill,

    "That the sum of $805,330 for Head 30 stand part of the Schedule."

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



    FIRST SCHEDULE

    Head 30-

    Question again proposed.

10.03 a.m.

    Mr William Tan (Tiong Bahru): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to refer to subhead 11 in page 190, Singapore Tourist Promotion. I notice here that we are to spend a sum of $369,730.

    Sir, I want an answer from the Minister for Commerce and Industry as to what Singapore can offer to tourists when they come here, as we are spending such a big amount on this Tourist Promotion Board. After all, we do not have in Singapore a snake temple or the Ayer Itam Temple, as they have in Penang, or in Hongkong where they have the Amarok. What we have are only swamp land and some fine buildings.

    People who come to Singapore are not interested in our fine buildings and roads. What have we got anyway? If we are going to spend such a big sum of money to attract tourists, we must

Column: 1450

also develop our place here in order that more tourists can be induced to come to Singapore.

    I am very perturbed to learn that the tourists, whenever they land in Singapore, are shown places like the death houses at Sago Lane. It happened on one occasion at these death houses, there were many bereaved families crying over their beloved ones who had passed away. The tourists entered the death house. They tramped in and out. They climbed up and down the stairs. Is it not pitiful? Why must the tourists be brought to that area?

    Sir, I would like to say this. Many people have not visited the death house. My father was in the death house one day, and I can say that on that same day tourists came to the house. It was really pathetic to see a bereaved family in those circumstances. They had lost someone very close to their hearts, and these tourists, mostly foreigners, when they went there, smiled, giggled, and shook their heads.

    If we are going to spend this money, we must develop Singapore. We must get some fine beaches or big hotels. At the moment, Sir, what have we got? We have only a few small hotels. The hotels which I visited, when I travelled in Europe and Japan, were very fine ones. They were big and had hundreds of rooms. This amount that we are going to spend is most ridiculous, unless we are going to develop our place here so that more people can come to Singapore, because tourism is another invisible export from which Singapore can get more income besides trade.

    Trade is very important. I have said on the Second Reading that we must allow all types of goods to come in. Make Singapore a free port whereby goods imported here can be re-exported to the various neighbouring countries. We can earn money on them. But the Government is not very concerned about the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Let us take a look at it. What experience has the Permanent Secretary

Column: 1451

to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry got? Sir, this is a very important Ministry. Trade is the lifeblood of Singapore. Yet, at the present moment, the Permanent Secretary in charge of this important Ministry has no qualifications and no experience. Neither has he any academic qualifications regarding trade or commerce, except an Honours degree on the Malay Kris.

    Sir, I am a merchant. I know that about three-quarters of the revenue is derived from trade. We live on trade. So if we are really interested in seeing that Singapore should get more dollars into the Treasury, we must develop trade. Put someone in charge of the Ministry who has the necessary qualifications and experience, not a man who knows nothing about trade or commerce, particularly industry. This is a shame. When I look through all these records. I am very perturbed to find that Singapore is not paying particular attention to this matter, in spite of the fact that we are spending the colossal sum of $805,330 on this item.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): At the close of yesterday's sitting, the hon. Member for Serangoon interjected to say that I had not given him a detailed reply to his point about shipping and shipping conferences. Sir, my failure to give a detailed reply was because of my desire not to prolong the debate unnecessarily. As I had pointed out, it was getting rather stale, and we were reaching almost the moment of interruption. However, since I have an opportunity this morning, I shall give a reply.

    It cannot be denied, Sir, that certain shipping conferences at certain times do exercise a strangling effect on our trade. This is not a new factor in our trading circumstances. It is a factor that has irked merchants many years. I am reminded of the same outcry against shipping conferences even before the war.

    I have got a cutting of the Singapore Free Press of 8th March, 1937. It was a morning paper at that time.

Column: 1452



"Autocracy of the Shipping Conferences harming the local entrepot trade.
Protest by the President of Indian Chamber of Commerce.


Independent Line from here to India?


    The autocracy of some of the Shipping Conferences was condemned by Mr Mohamed Jumabhoy,"

That was my father, Sir,

    "President of the Indian Chamber of Commerce, in his report for 1936 to the Annual General Meeting that was held yesterday..."

and then it goes on, for I have not got the full cutting. It has been eaten by white ants, I think! However, this factor has been very irksome to the merchants. Even Mr Tan Siak Kew, who is not in the House at the moment, has often told me that if the shipping conferences were more reasonable, we could develop our trade better, and I admit that frankly that would be so. However, it is not an easy task to fight these established shipping conferences, because they are very big and our resources are not adequate to fight them. Firstly, there is the financial question. Have we sufficient money to have enough of our own ships to operate in all the oceans where cargoes from Singapore are going? And what is the amount of tonnage required? The Member for Telok Ayer raised a very pertinent question yesterday, when he asked how much does a ship cost. One ship costs millions of dollars. Also when you really go out of your way to fight the shipping conferences, you come to a freight war. When you come to a freight war, what do you find? You find that in the end the merchants for whose benefit you are trying to break the conference will invariably, quietly and, under a different name possibly, go and ship by the conference lines because these conferences lines are able to offer cheaper freight rates. I am sure the Member for Telok Ayer will bear me out, because he has had the experience of fighting the Straits Bombay Conference in the 1930's. It is a tough fight. A merchant does not always look to the long-term advantage. If he can find cheaper freight immediately even with the conference line, he will go and quietly ship by the conference line which

Column: 1453

has entered the freight war. Therefore, any effort by any organisation or any country to fight the shipping conferences will be a very difficult task, unless they have powerful resources behind them, and it will take at least 10 or 15 years to develop shipping to the amount where they could reasonably hope to have a chance of fighting any of these conferences.

    The other question is lack of trained technical staff. We have not got locally trained technical staff. We have not got the Masters. We have not got the Mates. We have not got the Engineers to man ships which we might possibly own. It has been two years since I tried to expand the local trade limits for the local trade masters, provided they take extra subjects and pass them. We have worked long hours to finalise such a scheme. Then we put it to the Federation of Malaya and Borneo territories. But both of them turned it down. In fact, if the scheme had been operated, it would have benefited the Malays, because most of the local trade masters are Malays. But the Federation of Malaya could not see eye to eye with us. Neither did the Borneo territories. The hon. Member may well ask why do we not go alone on it? The answer is that we could not go alone because if our ships get out of Singapore and go to any of these areas, the Borneo Government or the Federation Government could refuse to give it a clearance and the ship would be stuck there. So any action to enlarge the local trade limits and raise the status of the local trade masters, so that they could command bigger ships with bigger tonnages, must have the approval of the Federation Government and the Borneo Government. We cannot do it on our own. That is roughly the position. However, if the hon. Member has any scheme in mind which will be workable, I should be happy to discuss it with him. But I sympathise with him when he said that the shipping conferences do have a strangle-hold effect on our commerce; and they could, if they want to fight us, divert our trade to other channels, as happened in copra recently.

Column: 1454



10.15 a.m.

    Now, coming to the subject of tourism raised by the Member for Tiong Bahru. He asked what we have got in Singapore. Sir, I had occasion recently to stop for a couple of days in Honolulu on my way to the United States, and frankly what I saw in Honolulu did not impress me at all. The much-publicised Waikiki Beach has nothing except that it is a beach with bathing facilities, basically the same as we have in Changi; except it is a bigger beach. Yet it is the publicity that has made Hawaii today a centre of big tourist attraction. They have nothing else to offer besides that.

    Mr William Tan: They have fine hotels.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: We offer shopping facilities here, and I am sure many of the tourists who come here do a lot of shopping in our stores. The Member raised the question of big hotels. There were two proposals I received last year for two big operators to have big hotels here. However, the proposals are still under consideration, and I am afraid that now they are rather sitting on the fence to see what sort of a government is returned after the next Elections before they would put in $5 million in a hotel.

    Then again, Sir, hon. Members must have read the comment made by Mr Tan Chin Tuan, Chairman of the Raffles Hotel, yesterday about the raising of electricity rates. Now, that has not been helpful to the hotel industry. The hon. Member for Tanjong Pagar may very well say that the City Council is responsible for selling electricity at an economic price, without caring what other industries the Government want to develop. That may be so, Sir. But then the City Council's responsibility is to license ice-cream sale only for health reasons, and not to prohibit the entry of ice-cream to encourage local industry. But they have done it, and if they can do it with ice-cream, they might also consider other industries.

    The Member for Tiong Bahru went on to say: "Make Singapore a free port." It is a free port, and I do not see how freer I can make it.

Column: 1455



    Then he went on to attack my Permanent Secretary. Sir, the appointment of a local officer as Permanent Secretary was the subject of an agreement reached under the Malayanisation Scheme. The Malayanisation Scheme was approved by hon. Members on both sides of the House. My present Permanent Secretary has been promoted to that post in accordance with the Malayanisation policy. He has not got any high academic degree, I admit, but then in the case of the Permanent Secretary to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, it has never been found necessary to have high academic degrees. In fact, as a merchant, I hold the view that sometimes high academic degrees are more a deterrent to, than an assistance in, carrying out the right policy, because the thinking of people who hold such academic degrees runs in certain grooves, and those grooves are taught to them on the pattern of the economy of Western countries. For instance, certain economists hold the view that this is the line we should take, because they have learnt their economics according to the pattern of Western economics. But these conditions do not apply here. Therefore, it is better to have a man who has not got a high academic degree in economics, but who has experience in handling the matter. I can tell you that this officer is a very promising officer, and I am sure he will develop into a very good Permanent Secretary.

    I have some experience in trade, as the hon. Member must admit, and I am there at least until 5th April, 1959, to guide the Ministry and to do my best to advance the cause of Singapore in commerce and industry.

    The hon. Member might also wish to know that it is the Public Service Commission which chooses the man, and when my former Permanent Secretary resigned, we were short of local officers. Sir,I may now add that my Permanent Secretary is a Raffles College graduate, and he has studied the subject of economics. He has a B.A. Honours (Cambridge) degree. This is an administrative appointment determined outside the control of Government. So this point of not having any academic qualification

Column: 1456

is again wrong. However, I am quite satisfied with the officer concerned. I am sure he will make good in his job.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): The hon. Minister seems to be getting impatient, but I think, according to the time-table, we are still on schedule.

    We are very happy indeed to hear that the Minister for Commerce and Industry has confidence in his Permanent Secretary. I think it is the right course to take, and I am very sorry to have to criticise my colleague on the Opposition Side who has criticised the appointment of the new Permanent Secretary, and whose view on this matter shows a certain degree of inferiority complex; namely, if a European is appointed, then there will be no query at all.

    Mr William Tan: That is nonsense!

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, I am happy that the Minister for Commerce and Industry has enlightened us on this point.

    Now, coming to the tourist trade. I wonder whether the Minister for Commerce and Industry can let the House know what exactly is in his mind when he says he wants to make Singapore an attractive centre of tourism. Of course, I hope the Minister does not intend to attract tourists into Singapore on the style of the Paris night clubs, the Tokyo geishas, or the Hongkong strip tease. On the question of Hawaiian dances, have we any hula hula dances here? Sir, I did mention last year that, much as we would like to boost tourism, we must at the same time safeguard the moral standard of this city. Therefore, I wish the Minister for Commerce and Industry could give us more details, since a year has elapsed when the question was first raised. What is in his mind when he says that he is confident he is able to make Singapore an attractive tourist centre?

    Mr William Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder what the Member for Changi knows about trade, when he touched on the question of the appointment of the new Permanent Secretary to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. I pointed out to this House that

Column: 1457

the Ministry of Commerce and Industry is a very important Ministry. I am not against any type of people - they may be Europeans, Indians, Malays or Chinese - put in charge of this Ministry. What I am concerned is that this Permanent Secretary, according to his past records, has failed in his examinations. He could not even get into the Malayan Civil Service. He actually entered the Museum service as a curator. Later on he was given a scholarship and when he went to England, he wrote a book entitled "Kris".

    The Chairman: Order. I think this is completely irrelevant to the debate. The hon. Member is, I think, wrong in criticising an appointment which, I take it, is an appointment by the Public Service Commission.

    Mr William Tan: That is what I say, Sir. This is most unfair because this is a very important Ministry. We must get someone with experience, because Singapore lives on trade. Even the Minister for Commerce and Industry has said that this is a very important Ministry. We live or die by trade. We must get someone who knows trade or industry so that the Ministry can be run properly. It is no use putting someone there who has no experience. Maybe the Minister for Commerce and Industry is right when he says that academic qualifications are not sufficient. What we want is a man with a practical knowledge of trade and industry.

    The Chairman: Order. I think the hon. Member has ventilated his grievance, and I do not think the subject should now be pursued any further.

    Mr William Tan: I was just trying to reply to the Member for Changi and the Minister for Commerce and Industry about this appointment, because it was they who said that I was against the appointment of the present Permanent Secretary, because the incumbent is a Malay and I do not like Malays. It is not that.

Column: 1458



    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: I did not say that.

    The Chairman: Order. I have indicated that I consider that the hon. Member has had ample opportunity to answer what has been said and that subject should now be closed.

    Mr William Tan: Now, Sir, we come to the reply given by the Minister for Commerce and Industry, regarding the question of a merger. He pointed out that we have a surplus population, and asked where this surplus population would go, except to the Federation of Malaya, and that he was looking forward to that. It is just like looking forward to something remote. It is like hoping to win the first prize of the Social Welfare Lottery of $350,000. That is only a dream. We must face facts. We cannot say: we have a surplus population, so where will the people go, unless we beg the Federation of Malaya to take in a part of our population. I wonder whether the Minister for Commerce and Industry is aware that in Singapore today even in the public service, we have Federation people here. Even the Permanent Secretary to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry came from the Federation. Look at the place of his birth. I can tell you offhand of the names of four or five people who came from the Federation of Malaya. There are many more people in Singapore who came from the Federation of Malaya. Yet the Minister talked about a surplus population and that we must have a merger. Sir, on the question of a merger, we have had a reply many times from the Federation - Government officials and the people alike - that they do not want merger. They went so far as to describe Singapore as a diseased hand. Is it not humiliating? Is it not degrading? I am very surprised that the Government does not realise that. The Government must have a thick face not to realise the rebuff we receive from the Federation every time we ask for a merger. The Federation of Malaya was serious when they said that they did not want merger. We have already been repulsed more than once by the Federation.

Column: 1459



    Look at the student problem. Our students are not allowed to cross the Causeway and yet Federation students are allowed to cross into Singapore. Is it not humiliating?

    Also, Sir, we have tariffs imposed on us. When goods go to the Federation we must pay a tariff. When Federation goods come in here, they have no need to pay a tariff. As I said on the Second Reading, it is not a dignified approach. The Government are more concerned with the Federation than with attempting to improve the lot of the people of Singapore. They do not face facts. They are not realistic. They talk about the problem of merger day in and day out until they quit the Government.

10.30 a.m.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, I think the subject of the appointment of my Permanent Secretary has been sufficiently ventilated.

    The Chairman: I have closed the subject.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: There is only one little point. It is very difficult to find good officers with enough experience. We have advertised for officers for other posts in the Ministry, for lower posts, and even then we have not been able to get the officers. We have kept on advertising.

    I also have plans to try and train a few junior officers as Trade Commissioners, but in our search for them we have not come across a suitable type.

    Coming, Sir, to tourism, a point raised by the Member for Changi, it is not our desire to have Singapore follow Paris or Japan with their night life. We want to encourage tourists to come here and study how other people live and to see the world.

    I may perhaps give a few figures here, Sir, of the contribution that tourism has made to Singapore's economy. We had a survey carried out for the period 1st July, 1957, to 30th June, 1958 - one year - and we found that of the number who landed in Singapore from overseas, 75,456 persons stayed an average of

Column: 1460

three days. There are other categories who stayed less than three days, but they are not included in this figure. Those who stayed three days and over spent an average of $100 a day. This amounts to $22,636 000 in tourist expenditure for the 12 months analysed. We hope to get a 10 per cent increase next year.

    Now, the countries from which the biggest number of such persons come here are: United States 10,774: United Kingdom 8,751: other European countries 8,223; India 5,486; other South Asian countries 15,123; Australia 4,956; and Indonesia 14,426. The other figures are in the region of a thousand or less than a thousand and I am not quoting them. As I have said, the total number of those tourists who stayed three days or over is 75,456, and their expenditure is over $22,000,000. So you can see the size of contribution that tourism makes to Singapore's economy.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    The sum of $805,330 for Head 30 ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Column: 1460



    Head 31-

    Question proposed,

    "That the sum of $109,130 for Head 31 stand part of the Schedule."

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, touching on Head 31 - Agriculture - I would like the Minister for Commerce and Industry to enlighten us on two points.

    The first is vegetable growing. I wonder if vegetable production has increased. Furthermore, because of floods or the limitation of land and, I think, also a lack of knowledge of nursing vegetable beds and shortage of suitable fertilizers, will that affect the production of vegetables?

    Secondly, is there any possibility of developing the flower-growing industry in Singapore?

    I wish the Minister will answer these two questions.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, we produce about 60 per cent of our requirements of green leaf vegetables in Singapore. That is quite a lot when taking into consideration the size of the island and the land available for such purposes.

Column: 1461



    We wanted to intensify agriculture on hilltop land, which is not fertile enough for normal methods of cultivation, by getting an expert from India on hydroponics - that is soilless culture. We were promised an expert in 1956. Unfortunately the expert did not turn up. For some reason, I think, his visit was cancelled and we could not obtain his services.

    The Rural Development Commissioner spoke to me a few days back. He said he was trying again to get such an expert from India. In fact, he is already trying out experiments in hydroponics in certain areas. If that succeeds, and if it is found to be an economic proposition, we can then increase our agricultural production - vegetable production - by quite a lot.

    Hon. Members may be interested to know that in July this year a record quantity of tobacco was harvested - two and a half times the average monthly harvest in 1957. The harvest was 142,816 pounds tobacco. That is not just accidental. That is due to the advice from Ministry officials who go out and encourage the farmers as to the lines of production. We do not force them to take certain lines of production but we encourage them in what lines they wish to take, and that is in keeping with the freedom of occupation.

    What I have said shows that the tobacco crop has greatly increased. Our vegetable production is steady and if we succeed in hydroponics, it will go up further.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, I think the Minister has forgotten to answer my point about the flower-growing industry, whether it is possible to develop flower plantations here?

    As a supplementary question, Sir, is it possible for the Minister to have a long-term policy to provide more farm lands for the professional farmers?

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The growing of flowers has also increased, Sir. In fact, the flower industry is becoming quite an export industry. But I am afraid I have not got the figures with me to show the hon. Member how it has progressed.

Column: 1462



    The provision of more land for farmers - that is a most difficult question, because we are short of land. That is why I say if we have a merger with the Federation we can settle some of them on their land. Land is a commodity which we cannot just create out of thin air. It is a god-sent thing.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: No, no.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: As I said yesterday, there is a lot of land available all over the world - under-populated land - but it is closed to us at the moment.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    The sum of $109,130 for Head 31 ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Column: 1462



    Head 32-

    Question proposed,

    "That the sum of $98,580 for Head 32 stand part of the Schedule."

    Mr William Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like the Minister for Commerce and Industry to tell me what are the functions of the Co-operative Development Department and for what purpose it is set up.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: It was not set up by me, Sir. It existed when I took office as Minister, and the hon. Member should have asked this question in 1955, when he first came into this House, because it was a department which had a grant in the Budget then.

    However, the Department is set up to encourage the development of Co-operative Societies.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, on this Head - Co-operative Development - I recollect that I filed a question last year whether the Government would be prepared to extend cash loans to certain Co-operative Societies. I remember, Sir, the Minister said they had a scheme to provide a certain amount, say $50,000, to the farmers or fishermen. I hope the Minister will take this opportunity to enlighten us, by giving details on the progress of such a scheme, and whether he intends to provide more money for such a scheme.

Column: 1463



    Furthermore, I wish him to give an answer whether or not he is satisfied with the progress of Co-operative Societies in Singapore. If not, what is the main cause? Is it because there is no financial support?

    Mr William Tan: Sir, the Minister for Commerce and Industry, in reply to my question about the functions of this Co-operative Development Department, said that it was going to look after the Co-operative Societies in Singapore.

    Sir, we are spending a sum of $98,580 on this Department. What I want to know is why the Department itself is not doing anything, except on paper? To register the Co-operative Societies in Singapore is not enough. I was told that this Department is to look after the interests of the farmers in the rural areas, to help them, but it is only on paper.

    I wonder how many times the Minister has said he would look into this problem of co-operative development. It is a mere waste to spend money on the staff in this Department.

    If the Minister were to study carefully the working system past and present in this Department, he would have a shock.

    I suggest, Sir, that a Committee be set up to look into the functions and duties of this Department. And I can tell you furthermore, Sir, that when this Committee investigate into the functions of this Department, you will be surprised; even the Minister will be surprised!

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, I myself am not satisfied with the progress made by the Co-operative Development Department. I have not been satisfied since quite some time in the past. There is nothing I can do about it, because we have not got suitably trained officers to run the Department. What we lack are Chinese Co-operative Officers who can speak the language and go out to the farmers and talk to them about the advantages of forming co-operatives. We could not get such men and I even

Column: 1464

said so last year during the Budget debate. I did my very best to get some officers, but we have not succeeded. Therefore, it is the physical limitation which we have not been able to overcome.

    Mr William Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a sorry admission by the Minister for Commerce and Industry that he is not satisfied with that Department. What has he done after all? Why cannot he improve? It is no use saying that he cannot get this officer; he cannot get that officer; he cannot recruit experienced officers. That is not enough.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are spending $98,580 of the people's money at the expense of the people of Singapore. If we are going to pay such a large sum to the staff of this Department, we should see that it is functioning properly and not wasting the money, as in this case.

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry just stands here and says, "I do not know. I admit that this Department is not very satisfactory. I have looked into it, but we cannot get the men." That is not the excuse we want.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: It is not a sorry admission, Sir,It is an honest admission. It is not just made today; it has been made a year ago. I do not know whether I can say this, Sir,I have tried to get another officer, but the Public Service Commission would not give me another officer. We are not dictators who could order the Public Service Commission about. And that is the end of the matter. I cannot do anything further than that. The Minister is limited by the appointment made by the Public Service Commission. Though I would like to have a Chinese as the Head of the Department, who could go put to the farmers (who are mainly Chinese) so that the co-operatives can progress further, I suppose the Public Service Commission have not been able to find a suitable man. Probably it is not their fault. Possibly it is because they cannot find a suitable man. That is why we are at the moment restricted, as I have explained.
